Detailed Description

A simple deterministic based automaton to handle the recognition of the various tokens that the language defines. To make recognition easier we store the string of each token alongside it's type in a std::map so once a token has been scanned, we can determine it's type in constant time. To add a new token to the scanner add a new enumeration value for it in TokenTypes.h and add code to one of the InitialiseXXX functions to add it to the token map so it will be recognised.

Internally the scanner buffers it's input to minimise the amount of file operations required. The exact size of the buffer is controlled by m_InputBufferSize and defaults to 4K. Refreshing of the buffer is handled automatically once it's detected that we're at the end of it, using a larger buffer could improve performance at the expense of more memory used whilst a smaller buffer lessens memory requirements but impacts performance as it will need to be refreshed more often.

bool CLexicalScanner::HasMoreTokens ( void   ) 

Determine if there are any more tokens to come.

Returns:
True if there are more tokens, false if there isn't.

Token_t CLexicalScanner::GetNextToken ( void   ) 

Get the next token from the input stream.

Returns:
A new Token_t object for the next token.

Token_t CLexicalScanner::PeekNextToken ( void   ) 

Take a look at the next token without actually consuming it. This will be the next token returned by GetNextToken. This only works for a single token lookahead, if more is required then the necessary tokens can be reinserted using PushbackToken.

Returns:
A new Token_t object for the peeked token.

void CLexicalScanner::PushbackToken ( Token_t  Tok  ) 

Push a token back into the input stream, this will be the next token returned on the next call to GetNextToken or PeekNextToken.

Parameters:
Tok Token to push back into the input stream.

void CLexicalScanner::ClearPeekedTokens ( void   ) 

Discard all peeked tokens.

long CLexicalScanner::CurrentLineNumber ( void   ) 

Query which line number we're processing.

Returns:
The line number we're processing.

Add the variable type tokens to the token map.

Add the control statement tokens - if/while etc to the token map

Add any tokens not covered above to the token map.

Eat whitespace and comments which are ignored.

Refresh the input buffer and reset m_ForwardPtr.

char CLexicalScanner::IncForwardPtr ( void   )  [private]

Increment the forward pointer and check to see if we've reached the end of the input buffer.

Returns:
The character at the current position.

void CLexicalScanner::ScanIdentifierToken ( void   )  [private]

Keep consuming characters from the input file until we reach a character which isn't part of an identifier. The value of the identifier after this function returns is in m_CurrTokenStr.

void CLexicalScanner::ScanDigitToken ( void   )  [private]

Like ScanIdentifierToken, only this time we're scanning a integral or floating point literal value. The literal value will be in m_CurrTokenStr after this function returns.

void CLexicalScanner::ScanStringToken ( void   )  [private]

Almost identifical to ScanIdentifierToken only this time we're scanning a string literal which is surrounded by double quotes. The scanned string will be in m_CurrTokenStr after this function returns.

TokenType CLexicalScanner::GetTokenType ( void   )  [private]

Determine the type of the token we have in m_CurrTokenStr.

Returns:
The exact type of the token just scanned.

Field Documentation

ifstream CLexicalScanner::m_FileHandle [private]

Handle to the file we're reading tokens from.

TokenMap CLexicalScanner::m_Keywords [private]

Token maps for keywords.

TokenMap CLexicalScanner::m_MiscTokens [private]

Token map for misc tokens not covered by m_Keywords.

char* CLexicalScanner::m_InputBuffer [private]

Buffer of characters read from the input file in one read operation to cut down on file IO and it's size.

const int CLexicalScanner::m_InputBufferSize [private]

The size of the input buffer being used.

string CLexicalScanner::m_CurrTokenStr [private]

We copy characters from the input buffer to this one whilst are in the process of determining the current token.

char* CLexicalScanner::m_ForwardPtr [private]

The forward pointer is the one we advance to scan for multiple characters tokens such as ">=" or "==" for example, the string of characters between the two pointers in the buffer is the token we're scanning.

long CLexicalScanner::m_CurrLineNumber [private]

Current line number we're scanning.

list<Token_t> CLexicalScanner::m_PeekedTokens [private]

If we've peeked at any token, they're stored here until we call GetNextToken again in which case we'll pop the top token and return that instead of reading from the file.

bool CLexicalScanner::m_PeekingAtToken [private]

Are we peeking at a token when we call GetNextToken?
